title: Question 49

children: A 55-year-old woman is hospitalized for increased daytime sleepiness that has progressed since discharge from the hospital 2 days ago. She had right knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis-related severe knee pain. She has a history of obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications are lisinopril, metformin, and liraglutide. In addition, she was discharged on oxycodone and enoxaparin.
On physical examination, respiration rate is 12/min; the remainder of the vital signs are normal. BMI is 44.

Chest radiograph shows small lung fields.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Hospitalized patients suspected of having obesity hypoventilation syndrome should be started on noninvasive ventilation with either bilevel positive airway pressure or volume-targeted pressure support.
More than 70% of patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome have severe obstructive sleep apnea; the diagnosis should be confirmed with polysomnography in a sleep laboratory.

). The patient has hypercapnic respiratory failure due to a combination of opiates (oxycodone) and obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), in which the obesity has led to mechanical changes that increase the load that the respiratory muscles must overcome. The addition of opiates decreased the respiratory drive in a patient that had underlying hypoventilation. BPAP delivers a higher level of positive airway pressure during inspiration than during expiration. In the acute setting, the difference between expiratory and inspiratory pressure helps the respiratory muscles generate appropriate tidal volumes. A backup respiratory rate can also be designated to initiate breaths in patients who have a low respiratory rate. The 2019 guidelines from the American Thoracic Society (ATS) recommend that hospitalized patients suspected of having OHS should be started on noninvasive ventilation with either BPAP or volume-targeted pressure support and continued on this therapy until they undergo outpatient evaluation for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), ideally during the first 3 months after hospital discharge.
